message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: The behavioral mechanisms governing collective motion in swarming locusts
Paper Abstract: Collective motion, which is ubiquitous in nature, has traditionally been explained by “self-propelled particle” models from theoretical physics. Here we show, through field, lab, and virtual reality experimentation, that classical models of collective behavior cannot account for how collective motion emerges in marching desert locusts, whose swarms affect the livelihood of millions. In contrast to assumptions made by these models, locusts do not explicitly align with neighbors. While individuals respond to moving-dot stimuli through the optomotor response, this innate behavior does not mediate social response to neighbors. Instead, locust marching behavior, across scales, can be explained by a minimal cognitive framework, which incorporates individuals’ neural representation of bearings to neighbors and internal consensus dynamics for making directional choices. Our findings challenge long-held beliefs about how order can emerge from disorder in animal collectives.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "desert locust"

Links: [{"title":"Desert locust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_locust"},{"title":"2019–2022 locust infestation","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019–2022_locust_infestation"},{"title":"Desert Locust Control Organization for Eastern Africa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_Locust_Control_Organization_for_Eastern_Africa"},{"title":"Locust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locust"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about desert locusts:

## Overview

Desert locusts are periodically swarming, short-horned grasshoppers found primarily in the deserts and dry areas of northern and eastern Africa, Arabia, and southwest Asia.(no content)The desert locust (Schistocerca gregaria) is probably the best known species owing to its wide distribution and its ability to migrate over long distances.

## Behavior and Life Cycle

Locusts differ from other grasshoppers in their ability to change from a solitary living form into gregarious, highly mobile, adult swarms and hopper bands, as their numbers and densities increase.(no content)The lifecycle of the desert locust consists of three stages: the egg, the nymph known as a hopper, and the winged adult.(no content)They have two to five generations per year.

## Threat Level

The desert locust is potentially the most dangerous of the locust pests because of the ability of swarms to fly rapidly across great distances.(no content)Swarms can travel up to 130 km a day in search of new vegetation and moist weather.

## Recent Infestations

Between June 2019 and February 2022, a major outbreak of desert locusts threatened food supplies in East Africa, the Arabian Peninsula and the Indian subcontinent. The outbreak was the worst to hit Kenya in 70 years, and the worst in 25 years for Ethiopia, Somalia, and India.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Links: [{"title":"Desert locust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_locust"},{"title":"2019–2022 locust infestation","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2019–2022_locust_infestation"},{"title":"Desert Locust Control Organization for Eastern Africa - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_Locust_Control_Organization_for_Eastern_Africa"},{"title":"Locust - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Locust"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about desert locusts:

## Overview

Desert locusts are periodically swarming, short-horned grasshoppers found primarily in the deserts and dry areas of northern and eastern Africa, Arabia, and southwest Asia.(no content)The desert locust (Schistocerca gregaria) is probably the best known species owing to its wide distribution and its ability to migrate over long distances.

## Behavior and Life Cycle

Locusts differ from other grasshoppers in their ability to change from a solitary living form into gregarious, highly mobile, adult swarms and hopper bands, as their numbers and densities increase.(no content)The lifecycle of the desert locust consists of three stages: the egg, the nymph known as a hopper, and the winged adult.(no content)They have two to five generations per year.

## Threat Level

The desert locust is potentially the most dangerous of the locust pests because of the ability of swarms to fly rapidly across great distances.(no content)Swarms can travel up to 130 km a day in search of new vegetation and moist weather.

## Recent Infestations

Between June 2019 and February 2022, a major outbreak of desert locusts threatened food supplies in East Africa, the Arabian Peninsula and the Indian subcontinent. The outbreak was the worst to hit Kenya in 70 years, and the worst in 25 years for Ethiopia, Somalia, and India.

Links: [{"title":"Self-propelled particles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-propelled_particles"},{"title":"Clustering of self-propelled particles - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Clustering_of_self-propelled_particles"},{"title":"Vicsek model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vicsek_model"},{"title":"Collective motion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_motion"},{"title":"Particle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle"},{"title":"Active Brownian particle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Active_Brownian_particle"},{"title":"Self-propelled - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-propelled"},{"title":"Particle (disambiguation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Particle_(disambiguation)"},{"title":"Self-propulsion - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-propulsion"},{"title":"Self-assembly - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-assembly"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about self-propelled particles:

## Definition and Overview

Self-propelled particles (SPP), also referred to as self-driven particles, are terms used by physicists to describe autonomous agents, which convert energy from the environment into directed or persistent random walk.

## Examples

Self-propelled particles span a wide range of systems:

- **Biological systems**: Natural systems which have inspired the study and design of these particles include walking, swimming or flying animals. Other biological systems include bacteria, cells, algae and other micro-organisms.

- **Artificial systems**: Self-propelled particles often refer to artificial systems such as robots or specifically designed particles such as swimming Janus colloids, bimetallic nanorods, nanomotors and walking grains.

## Collective Behavior

One of the most important aspects of self-propelled particles is their capacity for collective motion. Self-propelled particles interact with each other, which can lead to the emergence of collective behaviours. These collective behaviours mimic the self-organization observed with the flocking of birds, the swarming of bugs, the formation of sheep herds, etc.

## Applications

Chemotaxis of biological and synthesized self-propelled particles provides a way of directing motion at the microscale and can be used for drug delivery, sensing, lab-on-a-chip devices and other applications.

Web search results for query: "optomotor response"

Links: [{"title":"Optomotor response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optomotor_response"},{"title":"Four-eyed fish - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Four-eyed_fish"},{"title":"File:Optomotor Response.svg - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:Optomotor_Response.svg"},{"title":"H1 neuron - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/H1_neuron"},{"title":"Optogenetics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optogenetics"},{"title":"Optokinetic response - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optokinetic_response"},{"title":"Oculocardiac reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Oculocardiac_reflex"},{"title":"Corneal reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Corneal_reflex"},{"title":"Accommodation reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/?title=Accommodation_reflex"},{"title":"Vestibulo-ocular reflex - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vestibulo-ocular_reflex"}]

Based on the search results, here's what I found about the optomotor response:

## Definition and Basic Function

The optomotor response is an innate, orienting behavior evoked by whole-field visual motion and is common to fish and insects during locomotion, such as swimming, walking and flying.

## How It Works

The direction of the whole-field coherent motion dictates the direction of the behavioral output (e.g., leftward visual stimuli lead to turning left, and rightward visual stimuli lead to turning right).(no content)For instance, when zebrafish larvae are presented with a sinusoidal black and white grating pattern, the larvae will turn and swim in the direction of the perceived motion.

## Biological Purpose

The optomotor response is essential for animals to correct unplanned course perturbations while navigating through their environment, such as current shifts around a swimming fish or air gusts around flying insects.(no content)The response is rapid and instinctual, with pure delay times of just 20-40ms for fruit flies in flight.

## Research Applications

The optomotor response is frequently used as a behavioral assay. In zebrafish, the optomotor response is frequently used as a metric of visual performance as it can be reliably evoked from 7 days post fertilization throughout adulthood.(no content)In flies, the optomotor response is used to understand the functional properties of neural circuits in the context of a specific behavior and examine the sensorimotor transformations underlying that behavior.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "swarm behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Swarm (simulation) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(simulation)"},{"title":"Swarming (honey bee) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarming_(honey_bee)"},{"title":"Boids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boids"},{"title":"Stigmergy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Stigmergy"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robot_teams"},{"title":"Talk:Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Flock (birds) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flock_(birds)"},{"title":"Flocking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocking"}]

Here are the search results for **swarm behavior**:

## Overview

Swarm intelligence is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.(no content)The expression was introduced by Gerardo Beni and Jing Wang in 1989, in the context of cellular robotic systems.

## Natural Examples

Swarm behavior occurs across diverse species:

- **Honey Bees**: Swarming is a honey bee colony's natural means of reproduction, in which a single colony splits into two or more distinct colonies.

- **Insects**: Midges form swarms, dancing in the air, with swarming serving multiple purposes, including the facilitation of mating by attracting females to approach the swarm.

- **Birds**: Flocking is the behavior exhibited when a group of birds are foraging or in flight, generally believed to arise from the need for cover and protection from predators, governed by local rules that do not involve any central coordination.

- **Plants**: Plant roots display observable swarm behavior, growing in patterns that exceed the statistical threshold for random probability, with the primary function being the uptake of soil nutrients.

## Key Principles

Flocking behavior is simulated by agents that move according to three basic rules: separation, alignment and cohesion.(no content)Stigmergy produces complex, seemingly intelligent structures without need for planning, control, or even direct communication between agents, supporting efficient collaboration between extremely simple agents.

## Applications

The application of swarm principles to robots is called swarm robotics while swarm intelligence refers to the more general set of algorithms.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

- **Honey Bees**: Swarming is a honey bee colony's natural means of reproduction, in which a single colony splits into two or more distinct colonies.

- **Insects**: Midges form swarms, dancing in the air, with swarming serving multiple purposes, including the facilitation of mating by attracting females to approach the swarm.

- **Birds**: Flocking is the behavior exhibited when a group of birds are foraging or in flight, generally believed to arise from the need for cover and protection from predators, governed by local rules that do not involve any central coordination.

- **Plants**: Plant roots display observable swarm behavior, growing in patterns that exceed the statistical threshold for random probability, with the primary function being the uptake of soil nutrients.

## Key Principles

Flocking behavior is simulated by agents that move according to three basic rules: separation, alignment and cohesion.(no content)Stigmergy produces complex, seemingly intelligent structures without need for planning, control, or even direct communication between agents, supporting efficient collaboration between extremely simple agents.

## Applications

The application of swarm principles to robots is called swarm robotics while swarm intelligence refers to the more general set of algorithms.

Here are the key findings from my web search on collective behavior in biology:

## Definition and Scope

Collective animal behavior is a form of social behavior involving the coordinated behavior of large groups of similar animals as well as emergent properties of these groups.(no content)This can include the costs and benefits of group membership, the transfer of information, decision-making process, locomotion and synchronization of the group.(no content)Collective motion is defined as the spontaneous emergence of ordered movement in a system consisting of many self-propelled agents, and can be observed in flocks of birds, schools of fish, herds of animals and also in crowds and car traffic.

## Key Characteristics

According to Tamás Vicsek et al., collective behavior refers to the phenomenon that an individual unit's action is dominated by the influence of the 'others'.(no content)In a collective motion system, some key characteristics should be included: the units of the system should be similar to each other; the units should be moving with a nearly a constant absolute velocity and are able to change their direction; and the units in the system should be able to interact with fellow units and respond to environmental change.

## Functions and Benefits

Functions of animal aggregations may be grouped into the four following categories: social and genetic, anti-predator, enhanced foraging, and increased locomotion efficiency.

## Decision-Making

While the role of a leading matriarch in an elephant herd is well known, studies have shown that some animal species use a consensus approach in their collective decision-making process, with a recent investigation showing that small groups of fish used consensus decision-making when deciding which fish model to follow.

Here are the search results for "collective motion":

## Definition and Overview

Collective motion is defined as the spontaneous emergence of ordered movement in a system consisting of many self-propelled agents.(no content)It can be observed in everyday life, for example in flocks of birds, schools of fish, herds of animals and also in crowds and car traffic.

## Key Characteristics

In a collective motion system, some key characteristics should be included: the units of the system should be similar to each other; the units should be moving with a nearly constant absolute velocity and be able to change their direction; and the units in the system should be able to interact with fellow units and respond to environmental change.

## Research and Models

The Vicsek model is a mathematical model used to describe active matter, and collective motion and swarming are among the most studied phenomena.(no content)The model shows a phase transition from a disordered motion to large-scale ordered motion, where at low noise and large density, particles are globally aligned and move in the same direction (collective motion).

## Specific Applications and Examples

Collective motion research extends to various biological and synthetic systems. Collective cell migration describes the movements of group of cells and the emergence of collective behavior from cell-environment interactions and cell-cell communication, and is an essential process in embryonic development, wound healing and cancer spreading.(no content)Chemotaxis is a form of collective motion of biological or non-biological particles toward a fuel source or away from a threat, as observed experimentally in enzyme diffusion and also synthetic chemotaxis or phototaxis.

Web search results for query: "flocking behavior"

Links: [{"title":"Flocking - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocking"},{"title":"Boids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Boids"},{"title":"Swarm behaviour - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour"},{"title":"Flock (birds) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flock_(birds)"},{"title":"Flocking (texture) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flocking_(texture)"},{"title":"Flock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Flock"},{"title":"Birds of a feather flock together - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Birds_of_a_feather_flock_together"},{"title":"Mixed-species foraging flock - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mixed-species_foraging_flock"},{"title":"Collective animal behavior - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_animal_behavior"},{"title":"Talk:Boids - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Boids"}]

Here's an overview of flocking behavior based on the search results:

## Definition

Flocking is the behavior exhibited when a group of birds, called a flock, are foraging or in flight.(no content)Sheep and goats also exhibit flocking behavior. More broadly, the term "flocking" is sometimes applied, in computer science, to species other than birds, to mean collective motion by a group of self-propelled entities, a collective animal behaviour exhibited by many living beings such as fish, bacteria, and insects.

## How It Works

Flocking behaviour was simulated on a computer in 1987 by Craig Reynolds with the program Boids. This program simulates simple agents (boids) that move according to a set of three basic rules: separation, alignment and cohesion.(no content)They generally hold true in the case of bird flocking, but the long range attraction rule (cohesion) applies to the nearest 5–10 neighbors of the flocking bird and is independent of the distance of these neighbors from the bird.

## Benefits

Flocking offers foraging benefits and protection from predators, although flocking can have costs for individual members. For example, a bird is now less likely to be attacked by a predator because predators have a lower success rate when attacking large flocks. The ability to avoid predation is one of the most important skills necessary in order to increase one's fitness.

More broadly, the term "flocking" is sometimes applied, in computer science, to species other than birds, to mean collective motion by a group of self-propelled entities, a collective animal behaviour exhibited by many living beings such as fish, bacteria, and insects.

## How It Works

Flocking behaviour was simulated on a computer in 1987 by Craig Reynolds with the program Boids. This program simulates simple agents (boids) that move according to a set of three basic rules: separation, alignment and cohesion.(no content)They generally hold true in the case of bird flocking, but the long range attraction rule (cohesion) applies to the nearest 5–10 neighbors of the flocking bird and is independent of the distance of these neighbors from the bird.

## Benefits

Flocking offers foraging benefits and protection from predators, although flocking can have costs for individual members. For example, a bird is now less likely to be attacked by a predator because predators have a lower success rate when attacking large flocks. The ability to avoid predation is one of the most important skills necessary in order to increase one's fitness.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "The behavioral mechanisms governing collective motion in swarming locusts". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification**: **contribution** - The paper proposes a new theoretical framework for understanding collective motion in locusts that challenges classical models.

**Key Findings**:
- **6 triples** were extracted and validated
- **Paper Type**: Contribution (creates novel theory)
- **Entity Distribution**: 5 concept entities, 1 data entity

**Extracted Triples**:

1. **Collective motion** (concept, proposes) - The paper's core contribution explaining how collective motion emerges through neural representation and consensus dynamics

2. **Self-propelled particles** (concept, uses) - Classical physics models that the paper contrasts against and shows cannot account for locust behavior

3. **Desert locust** (data, uses) - The primary study organism investigated through field, lab, and virtual reality experiments

4. **Swarm behaviour** (concept, uses) - The swarming phenomenon being studied and explained in the paper

5. **Optomotor response** (concept, uses) - An innate visual behavior shown to not mediate social response to neighbors in locusts

6. **Collective animal behavior** (concept, uses) - The broader field whose fundamental beliefs the paper challenges

**Validation**: ✅ All 6 triples passed validation with correct Wikipedia URLs and entity classifications.

Sources:
- [Collective motion](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_motion)
- [Self-propelled particles](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-propelled_particles)
- [Desert locust](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Desert_locust)
- [Swarm behaviour](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_behaviour)
- [Optomotor response](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Optomotor_response)
- [Collective animal behavior](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_animal_behavior)
